prospects.name: Endurance 1.5
prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs.

​

This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing. Steady Long Endurance rides are one of the best ways to cap off a long 2 or 3-week training block when your fatigue is high and your legs are tired, but you have just a bit more to squeeze out of yourself before you take your rest week. Shorter Endurance rides (like this one) can fit in both a hard week of training and a recovery week. That is, only if you do it right! Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles."

​

Truth be told, a proper Zone 2 ride, especially one under 90 minutes should not leave you fatigued or your legs wasted.

So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like? For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70%, but not over. (To spice things up, we have broken this session into 10-minute segments alternating from 60 to 65% of FTP.) Your heart rate should be sitting in low to mid Zone 2 heart rate, which is 70-80% of LTHR up to 85% of LTHR, but not for long. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can; for most this is 80-90rpm. Also, your RPE should be a 2-4 on a scale of 1-10.

​

Sounds simple right? It's actually one of the harder sessions to get right because you spend most of the time questioning why you are riding so easy, and if this is really going to make you fitter and faster, but you will have to trust us on this one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions, or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

​

**Warm Up**

5 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 1

Rest Between Sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats Per Set: 4

**Interval**

10 minutes @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

**Extra Volume**

NA

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: The Omnium
prospects.description:
Do you know what we love about you? Your versatility. You can Suffer anywhere, anytime, and in any way. That's why Grunter von Agony, Sufferlandrian Team Director, is sending you to compete in The Omnium at the UCI World Track Championships. Over the course of 50 minutes, you'll do battle in the six different races.

​

No two intervals in this workout are the same, with each one working slightly different Neuromuscular (NM), Anaerobic Capacity (AC), and Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP) variations. No need for FTP here, friends. It's the perfect session to improve top-end power without having to do a ton of repetitive efforts.

​

The Scratch Race and Flying Lap have an easy enough lead-in that you get to put your max sprint to the full test. Add in the standing starts for the Individual Pursuit and Kilo, and you give your NM a real run-through. The repeated surges of the Elimination Race, the all-out nature of the Kilo, and the massive efforts you have to make in the points race really test your powers of recovery while working your AC all the way to the max.

​

Since the efforts come in quick succession, and with most being over four minutes in length, your cardiovascular system never catches a real break, ensuring your MAP doesn’t get left out of the equation.

prospects.name: Tempo Alternating Cadence: 2 x 20
prospects.description: This one-hour session is highlighted by two twenty-minute efforts at 80-90% FTP. The first effort includes varying higher and lower cadence efforts, while the second effort is progressive in both intensity and cadence throughout. You only get 6-minutes of recovery between these two long efforts, so while not a maximal effort session - it'll challenge you!

prospects.name: Found in America
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2020): After finishing the Race Across America on the podium, Dave Haase is coming back to win it. But is that what he's really looking for? Is there more to why he's taking on such a formidable challenge than the pursuit of victory alone? This is an honest look at the demands of a legendary ultra-endurance race and what one finds out on the road.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: UAE Tour 2
prospects.description:
**Featured Rider: **Andrea Vendrame

**Event:** UAE Tour

**Mission - “Sniper”:** It’s Stage 6 of the UAE Tour and the peloton is entering the final 20km of the race. While not an out-and-out sprinter, you’re the fast man of the AG2R Citroen team. You don’t have a leadout so you’re on your own to grab a result. Do you have what it takes to go it alone and secure the win?

​

**About ProRides**

Here’s your chance to experience what it’s like to ride in the biggest races in the world, thanks to SYSTM’s 4DP platform. We’ve taken the first-person camera footage and power data from a pro cyclist and analyzed it to determine which part of their 4DP® profile each of their efforts corresponds to. But since few of us can put down pro-level watts, we made it so all of the efforts are scaled to your own personal 4DP® profile. That means you get to experience exactly what the pros experience relative to your own abilities. When they sprint, you sprint. When they attack, you attack. When they sit up, you get to take it (relatively) easy. It's the most immersive, realistic race simulation out there.

​

[Here's some more information on how to create the most immersive ProRides experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterProRides)

​

**Featured Footage: **Velon

prospects.name: Igniter
prospects.description:
A highly tuned machine needs its engine warmed up in order to produce the most power as efficiently as possible. Igniter is based on the highly successful warm-up session developed by British Cycling and used by Team Sky as part of their 'marginal gains' program. You'll go through a series of progressive efforts before hitting a couple of high-intensity/high-cadence sprints. You'll emerge ready to CRUSH EVERYTHING BEFORE YOU! This workout is perfect before major events, in conjunction with our Extra Shot workout, or to extend your regular session.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to why warm-ups are so important in this episode of The Knowledge podcast by Wahoo Sports Science:

[https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine](https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine)

prospects.name: Strade Bianche 1
prospects.description:
**Featured rider:** Tosh Van der Sande of Belgium

**Event:** Strade Bianche

**Mission - "The Scout":** Welcome to the famous white roads of Tuscany: dusty, unpredictable, and unbelievably hilly. You got in the early break to take the pressure off your teammates. By giving them a bit of a rest early on they'll have a better chance of making a move as the race winds towards the iconic finish in the picturesque hill town of Sienna. Your job is to make sure everybody in the break works well together to maintain a gap and hold off the peloton for as long as you can. The other teams' star riders are breathing down your neck. How long can you keep them at bay?

​

**About ProRides**

Here’s your chance to experience what it’s like to ride in the biggest races in the world, thanks to SYSTM’s 4DP platform. We’ve taken the first-person camera footage and power data from a pro cyclist and analyzed it to determine which part of their 4DP® profile each of their efforts corresponds to. But since few of us can put down pro-level watts, we made it so all of the efforts are scaled to your own personal 4DP® profile. prospects.description:

​

It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can, for most this is 80-90rpm and your RPE should be a 2-4 on a scale of 1-10.

You will have to trust us on that one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions! Or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

​

**Warm-Up**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 11

Rest Between Sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats per Set: 1

**Interval**

10 minutes @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

prospects.name: Recovery Spin
prospects.description:
Don’t be afraid of the Two Rs: rest and recovery. Believe it or not, you get faster when your body is taking it easy after all that suffering. A recovery spin is a very low intensity ride, so easy that you’d feel embarrassed to ride so slowly if you didn’t know you were helping your body get so much faster.

​

A good recovery spin is done at a cadence above 90 RPM. While keeping power below 50% of FTP, or an RPE less than 2.5, and keeping your heart rate in Zone 1 the entire time. Recovery spins can be done outdoors, but due to the low power demands, they are often easier done on the trainer. Resist the voice of your inner Sufferlandrian telling you to go faster.

​

**Main Set**

30 minute @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP-- HR <70%

prospects.name: Cadence Builds
prospects.description:
One of the best sessions for neuromuscular training, this drill asks you to progressively build from a cadence of 90 RPM to your MAX over 30 seconds, recover, and repeat several times. Cadence builds improve how you recruit your leg, gluteal, and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke by progressing to your maximal cadence. By reaching your highest cadence possible, you are training the 'on/off' switch in each muscle group to not only work faster but to have less overlap with your other muscle groups. This session trains your hamstring muscles to 'turn off' when your quads 'turn on' and vice-versa, resulting in a more efficient pedal stroke at both high and low cadences.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to The Knowledge podcast, by Wahoo Sports Science - The Benefits of High Cadence Training: [https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence](https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence)

prospects.name: 14 Vise Grips
prospects.description:
You can never have too many tools in the shed. After years of lobbying, we finally convinced Grunter von Agony to share his favorite set of implements with us: the fabled _14 Vise Grips_. Taken individually, each of the 14 intervals might appear tame, incapable of inflicting a significant squeeze. But when expertly applied in the correct order, they apply just the right kind of pressure to turn a Couchlandrian into a Sufferlandrian, just like turning coal into diamonds.

​

While the duration of each Vise Grip varies (from 30 seconds to 2 minutes), the power targets and recovery durations between them remain constant. The first 30-second interval should feel like a Sunday stroll in the park, but by the end of the first 2-minute Vise Grip, you'll be cursing Grunter's name. As the intervals get shorter, time will appear to stretch. That final 30-second effort will feel like an eternity. When you roll up to the second set, you'll know what you're in for, so just put your head down and prepare yourself to crush or be crushed.

​

Once you make it through all 14 Vise Grips, you will have been north of your Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP) for a total of 16 minutes. Changing the duration of the efforts (while keeping the same recovery) stresses your Anaerobic Capacity (AC) in a more dynamic way than, say, a more straightforward on/off session like _Half is Easy_. Since the longer efforts have the same recovery duration as the shorter ones, you will eventually deplete your AC, forcing your body to rely on your MAP to hit the required power targets. As the intervals get shorter in the second half of each set, you'll find that you have just enough left in the tank to complete the next effort.

​

Ultimately this workout combines the advantages of shorter, higher-power intervals with longer recovery (great for building muscular strength) with the advantages of longer, higher-power intervals with inadequate recovery (great for driving up your MAP and improving your AC).

prospects.name: Chasing the Sun
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2023): Fresh from a sold-out tour of UK cinemas, Chasing The Sun is the new documentary film from 2x BAFTA-winning director Michael B.Clifford. It explores extraordinary personal stories of ordinary cyclists taking on iconic endurance event Chase The Sun, revealing the power of the humble bicycle to transform lives and help save the planet.

The film features contributions from broadcaster and ITV’s voice of the Tour de France Ned Boulting, author and blogger Jools Walker, Turner Prize-winning artist Sir Richard Long and 4x Mountain Bike World Champion Tracy Moseley.

​

🚴 Workout: the workout accompanying this film varies from endurance to tempo to sub-threshold. The higher intensity efforts aren't the hardest you'll experience so that you can keep your attention on the film, however, they are just hard enough to help improve your FTP, oxygen utilization efficiency, and the ability to recover quickly between hard efforts. The workout intensity reflects the intensity of the riders in many places, so you may feel as if you're climbing Mont Ventoux or that you're a part of Cav's lead-out train on the run into the finish line.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: From the Ground Up - Season 1 Pt 2
prospects.description:
🎬 Film: Roberta, Shawna and Enzo have been training hard for the past 6 months. Share their journey as they arrive in Leadville and take on the Leadville Trail 100 Mountain Bike Race. Focusing on education and inclusivity, the series aims to make the sport of cycling less intimidating and more approachable while inspiring riders of all abilities to take on a challenge of their own!

​

🚴Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

prospects.name: MAP: 3 x 2
prospects.description:
The goal of this session is to accumulate a significant amount of time near your VO2max, or the point at which your body is consuming as much oxygen as it possibly can. That means your heart rate and breathing rate will both be near their max by the end of each interval, especially in the final few intervals.

​

Since it takes time for your heart rate and breathing rate to match your effort, for the first part of each interval, you will be tapping into your Anaerobic Capacity to produce the required power. To account for this, we have limited the recovery duration to be equal to the interval duration. Limited recovery ensures that you will drain your Anaerobic Capacity before the end of the intervals, meaning your body will be forced to produce as much power as possible using oxygen.

​

**Warm Up**

10 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <65%

7 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <75%

2 minute @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <85%

3 minute @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <90%

30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

30 seconds @ RPE 9 -- 90-95% of AC (130-180% of FTP)

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 1

Rest Between Sets: N/A

Interval Repeats Per Set: 3

**Interval**

Effort: 2 minutes @ RPE 9 -- 95-105% of MAP (115-135% of FTP)

Recovery: 6 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

​

**Extra Volume**

NA

​

**Cool Down**

8 minutes @ RPE 1 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Endurance 2.5
prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are just times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs.

​

This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing. Steady Long Endurance rides are one of the best ways to cap off a long 2 or 3-week training block when your fatigue is high, your legs are tired, but you have just a bit more to squeeze out of yourself before you take your rest week, but only if you do it right! Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles."

​

Truth be told, a proper Zone 2 ride should not leave you fatigued or your legs wasted. So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like? For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70% is ok, but not over. (To spice things up, we have broken this session into 10-minute segments alternating from 60 to 65% of FTP.) Your heart rate should be sitting in mid to low Zone 2 heart rate, which is 70-80% of LTHR, up to 85% of LTHR, but not for long. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can, for most this is 80-90rpm. Also, your RPE should be a 2-4.

​

Sounds simple right? It's actually one of the harder sessions to get right because you spend most of the time questioning why you are riding so easy, and if this is really going to make you fitter and faster. You will have to trust us on that one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions! Or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

​

**Warm-Up**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 7

Rest Between Sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats per Set: 1

**Interval**

10 minutes @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <85%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

2 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Cadence Builds
prospects.description:
One of the best sessions for neuromuscular training, this drill asks you to progressively build from a cadence of 90 RPM to your MAX over 30 seconds, recover, and repeat several times. Cadence builds improve how you recruit your leg, gluteal, and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke by progressing to your maximal cadence. By reaching your highest cadence possible, you are training the 'on/off' switch in each muscle group to not only work faster but to have less overlap with your other muscle groups. This session trains your hamstring muscles to 'turn off' when your quads 'turn on' and vice-versa, resulting in a more efficient pedal stroke at both high and low cadences.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to The Knowledge podcast, by Wahoo Sports Science - The Benefits of High Cadence Training: [https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence](https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence)

prospects.name: Tapers
prospects.description:
When it comes to "peaking", or performing at your absolute best on a given day, the key is nailing your Taper. The term "Taper" refers to how you train in the week or so before your target event to ensure you deliver your best performance. Generally, tapering means reducing your total training volume but continuing to hit some high-intensity efforts. While there are individual variations in the best way to taper, this session has been used by countless professionals leading into the biggest races of their lives -- athletes like World Champions Rohan Dennis and Flora Duffy.

​

With 3 sets of micro-intervals (40/20s, 30/30s, and 20/40s) you will hit your system with just enough intensity to keep your legs sharp and responsive, without adding any real fatigue. Outside of those 3 sets of micro-intervals, this session is purposefully short and easy. This is a preparation session, not a training session! After all, your event is just around the corner and all of the important training is behind you. Riding harder or longer today will do absolutely nothing to increase your fitness by event day; in fact, all that would do is increase your fatigue, which will only hurt your performance. Rather, this session makes sure your body is humming along and ready to perform on the big day.

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Puerto de la Vall de Ebo (Recharger Ride)
prospects.description:
This is an active recovery ride built with purpose. Low-intensity endurance work is paired with brief high-cadence neuromuscular activations to keep the nervous system awake without creating new fatigue. You’ll stay well below threshold throughout, allowing your body to absorb previous hard sessions and prepare for what’s ahead.

​

Set on the peaceful roads leading to the summit of Port de la Vall d’Ebo, this ride promotes circulation, technique, and mental reset. It’s ideal after race days or big training blocks — a smart session that helps you recover better, so you can train harder tomorrow. No ego, no watts chasing — just intentional recovery done right.

​

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/13996505846)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Primers
prospects.description: Whether you have a 4DP® fitness test coming up, a group ride you want to smash, that event you have been training all winter for, or even just a fun route you want to have a great ride on, this is the perfect session to do the day before. Unlike other SYSTM sessions, this one should not be viewed as a stand-alone “training” session, but rather, the ace up your sleeve you pull out when that big ride comes around. The key to this session is having you spend just enough time right around threshold, with sufficient recovery between efforts and a handful of sprints to prime all of your systems for tomorrow's event.

prospects.name: Full Frontal (4DP Assessment)
prospects.description:
Full Frontal: The Complete One.

We recommend the Full Frontal 4DP fitness assessment for:

- Experienced riders.
- Athletes with experience pacing maximal efforts / fitness testing.
- Those about to start—or who have just finished—a training plan.

This is our full 4DP fitness test and is the only test that exposes every aspect of your unique physiology in a single hour. Developed by Head of Wahoo Sports Science Coach Neal Henderson, Full Frontal uses the same lab-verified testing protocol that Coach Neal has used at the highest level for over a decade with professional and amateur athletes.

​

This test will provide you with a complete Four-Dimensional Power profile, identify your Rider Type, and tell you exactly what aspects of your fitness you need to focus on to become a more complete cyclist. More importantly, SYSTM will then use your results to set personalized power targets for all of your workouts based on your unique profile, resulting in the most precise, effective workouts available. Your results will also be used to tailor all of your training plans.

​

We recommend re-testing with Full Frontal every 8-12 weeks or as prescribed by your training plan.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[Why Fitness Testing Matters](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/testing-testing-1-2-3-why-fitness-testing-matters)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Sports Science

​

[Here's some more information on how to get the most from your fitness test.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterFitnessAssessment)

Setting concrete, actionable goals will keep you motivated and on track; whether you’re eyeing the top podium step or the summit of the local climb. We will help assess where you are today, where you want to go, and identify the steps needed to get there.

In this module, you will enable consistent progress by creating a habit of identifying monthly and weekly goals, with weekly rewards for achieving those goals.

prospects.name: Chest Opener
prospects.description:
This sequence is designed to open up the chest and improve mobility in the spine and shoulders. It includes stretches for the forearms, shoulders, chest, hip flexors, hamstrings, and calves. The poses are particularly effective for alleviating pain between the shoulder blades. This sequence is ideal as a post-workout routine, especially after working the chest or engaging in activities that involve a closed-chest posture. It is also beneficial after a day spent hunched over a computer.

​

The objectives are to open up the chest, enhance mobility in the spine and shoulders, stretch the forearms, shoulders, chest, hip flexors, calves, and hamstrings, and help alleviate pain between the shoulders.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Cat–Cow with Forearm Stretch
- Puppy
- Half-Twisted Scorpion
- Downward Dog
- Low Lunge with Chest Opener
- Kneeling Cat-Cow
- Camel
- Wide-Knee Child’s Pose
- Reclining Butterfly (on blocks)

prospects.name: Peak Pose Wheel
prospects.description:
This sequence builds towards the advanced backbend, Wheel pose. To prepare for this pose, the routine focuses on mobilizing the spine and shoulders and opening up the fronts of the hips. It is best practiced when fully warmed up, with careful attention to the lower back and only moving within safe ranges of motion. For those who can practice Wheel safely, it serves as an excellent counterpose to common postures from cycling or sitting at a desk, potentially alleviating lower back, upper back, and shoulder pain. For those not yet ready for Wheel, the other poses in this sequence are also effective for addressing muscular imbalances.

​

The objectives are to increase spinal and shoulder mobility, stretch the abs, chest, and fronts of the shoulders, open up the hip flexors, activate the glutes, and help alleviate lower and upper back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Supported Bridge
- Thunderbolt—Shoulder Rolls
- Kneeling Cat-Cow
- Puppy
- Downward Facing Dog
- Cobra
- Low Lunge with Shoulder Opener
- Bridge
- Wheel
- Windscreen Wipers

prospects.name: Recovery Booster
prospects.description: It may seem counterintuitive, but it's during recovery when you actually get stronger and consolidate the gains you've made while training. prospects.description: You've just finished a difficult training session. You probably just want to curl up in a ball, but to make sure your body stays limber and flexible this sequence will stretch you out and open you up. You'll be ready to hit it again in no time.

prospects.name: Classic Yoga Flow
prospects.description:
This classic, hip-focused sequence enhances mobility in the spine and hips while stretching the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, and groin, and strengthening the quads and hips. As you become familiar with the routine, you can work on synchronizing your breath with your movements, aiming to breathe in and out through your nose throughout. It is an excellent practice for the morning to sharpen your focus or directly after a workout to help prevent muscle stiffness.

​

The objectives are to improve mobility in the spine and hips, strengthen the hips and quads, stretch the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, and groin, and practice synchronizing breath and movement.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- High Lunge (+ Twist)
- Downward Dog
- Warrior 2
- Triangle
- Squat
- Final Resting Pose

This slow and stretchy sequence is ideal for practicing at the end of a long day at work or after travel. It focuses on opening up the chest and shoulders, stretching the neck and forearms, and releasing tension in the calves, hamstrings, hips, and lower back. These poses can also be used after a workout for a comprehensive full-body stretch.

​

The objectives are to stretch the neck, shoulders, triceps, chest, and forearms; release tension in the lower back, hips, hamstrings, calves, ankles, and feet; transition the body into parasympathetic "rest or digest" mode after exercise; and help alleviate lower and mid back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Puppy
- Screaming Toe
- Neck Stretch
- Ankle Stretch
- Chest Stretch
- Forearm Stretch
- Downward Dog
- Revolved Standing Forward Bend
- Low Lunge Chest Opener
- Dead Pigeon
- Reclining Spinal Twist

prospects.name: Breathing to Calm Down I
prospects.description: 3-Part Breath is a therapeutic breathing technique that encourages you to use your full lung capacity. This can help improve your ability to take in oxygen on the bike, as well as help you stay calm on focused when the pressure is on.

prospects.name: Recovery Booster
prospects.description: It may seem counterintuitive, but it's during recovery when you actually get stronger and consolidate the gains you've made while training. Without proper recovery, you won't improve. This session helps boost your recovery time, relaxing you and ensuring you give your body the chance to grow stronger.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine II
prospects.description: You've just finished a difficult training session. You probably just want to curl up in a ball, but to make sure your body stays limber and flexible this sequence will stretch you out and open you up. You'll be ready to hit it again in no time.

prospects.name: Breathing More Deeply
prospects.description: Diaphragmatic Breathing is a calming exercise that encourages you to breathe deeply into your abdomen. This can help improve your ability to take in oxygen on the bike, as well as help you stay calm on focused when the pressure is on.
